p.s: Delaney's mental state becomes increasingly more irrational and paranoid throughout the novel.
The passage, especially compared to the beginning of story, showcases the development of Delaney's from racist thoughts to racist actions.
When Delaney spots the car of José Navidad, he seems to fall into a kind of trance, since he shuts out everything from his surroundings and only focuses on finding José.
Here it becomes clear, that he starts becoming obsessed with the idea of criminals invading the area and he feels like he must protect everything (ll. 5-8).
The racist motivation behind Delaney's actions become apparent multiple times throughout the passage: [...] something that struck him with the force of a blow: the man was Mexican (ll. 16f).

The fact that he puts such an emphasizeemphasis on the ethnicity of this stranger shows that his prejudice is affecting his ability to view the situation objectively by immediately having his racist thoughts spill through.

Another moment that underlines this thesis, is when Delaney starts making all these judgements of José Navidad, even though cannot prove most of them [...] The man was a thief, a liar [...] a Mexican (ll. 49f).
What is speciallyespecially strickingstriking here is that his rampage of insults at José and ends with him being from Mexican decentdescent.
In that context, Delaney must think that being from Mexico is bad and shameful and puts it on the same level as being a criminal.
This again underlines the racist tone of Delaney's think processesthought processes.

Furthermore, he also tells explicitly tells José that he doesn't belong here (l. 39), which one hand aligns with Delaney wanting him off of the privatprivate property, but on the other hand illustrates that he should not be here, because of his ethnical background, since Arroyo Blanca is predominantly white.
Another aspect is that Delaney constantly feels threatened and or disrepected by Mexicans.
When José reached into his pocket to get the flyers, Delaney immediately thinks that he is armed and he will have to fight him (l. 55).
This being his first reaction depicts his paranoia towards Mexican immigrants being violent, when he was the one who actually became physical at first.
The fact that he cannot see this irony also just shows that his is too caught up in judging others.
Also the fact that José does not take him serious really aggrasete Delaney.

This being a recurring topic for him in his life, being ignored or belittled, it is noticeable that only when he is talking to a Mexican he builds up the confidence to stand up for himself, which shows that he thinks he has the right to decide what immigrants are allowed to do or not, which again illustrates his racist way thinking (ll. 40-45).
When he realizes that José is distributing flyers he feels deeply ashamed of his irrational actions.
Here it is visible that he is still able to reflect on his actions and knowknows that his behaviour is wrong (ll. 60-61).

But if taken into the bigger plot of the novel, these moments of reflection happen often, but especially towards the end, although Delaney is aware of his unfair prejudice, he is not willing to change, since the guilt he feels after wrongfully accusing immigrants is always temporary.

Regarding the narrator devices, this excerpt is mainly written in showing mode, which let'slets the readers really in on the emotions and thoughts of Delaney, which helps to illustrate the instable state of mind of the protagonist.

In conclusion, the passage is an important turning point in the negative development of Delaney Mosshacker, because the shift from him trying to surpress his racist thoughts and always feeling guilty because of them to overtly and aggressivlyagressively confronting immigrants out of groundless and racist suspicion, becomes most apparent here and only worsens over the rest of the storyline.
